Ye who recline on sofa or on chair,</br>Supine and idle, having nought to do;</br>If chance no gouty member seeks your care,</br>Nor deep brown study more engageth you;</br>Take up my rhymes, and read one line or two,</br>And, if they please you, read a little more:</br>If not, you cannot have great cause to rue,</br>Since then you know what you knew not before;</br>Tell, then, your neighbour so — the rhyme is quite a bore!

Oft have I chanced, with studious look, to spy,</br>At country fair, and eke in borough town,</br>A man and woman, with their little fry,</br>That humbly wander'd life's low vale adown:</br>In sooth, they were not held in small renown,</br>Albeit they could not boast of money bags;</br>For if their purse contain'd but half-a-crown,</br>And if their backs were cover'd, though with rags,</br>They car'd for nothing more — these philosophic wags.

The luckless husband was most sadly shent,</br>For he had been in battle's bickering fray;</br>And now, unfit to march in regiment,</br>He was disbanded from the ranks away,</br>Withouten aught of pension or of pay;</br>Nathless his country owed him for his blood;</br>One only eye did look upon the day,</br>And only on one living leg he stood—</br>For why?  the other limb was made of beechen wood.

Yet he was fit for trade of many a kind,</br>And oft along the busy streets was seen,</br>Yshouting "Scizzors ho!  and knives to grind,"</br>The while he trundled on his huge machine:</br>And he did make the weapons sharp and clean,</br>While rasping them upon the whirling stone,</br>By which your gums with spittle fill'd had been,</br>While showers of fire around the grinder shone,</br>Until he laid the steel upon a smoother stone.

At times this office would he casten by,</br>And somewhat nobler occupation reach;</br>New Almanacks at Christmas would he cry,</br>Whose pages many a coming wonder teach:</br>And now he vended last and dying speech</br>Of malefactor hung on gallows tree;</br>Wherein the luckless wretch was made to preach,</br>That people all, of high and low degree,</br>Should timeous warning take, and honest beings be.

His loving mate yclad in mantle red,</br>Of different kinds — some nappy and some bare;</br>And darn'd, I ween, with many a colour'd thread,</br>Which deftly show'd her needle's busy care;</br>Ane old straw bonnet she was proud to wear;</br>Her face was much imbrown'd with summer's heat;</br>In elfin tresses curl'd her raven hair;</br>And, though her apron was both clean and neat</br>She was withouten shoon or sandals to her feet.

Ane creeking basket on her arm she bore,</br>Fill'd with the potter's cunning work of clay,</br>With which she nimbly sped from door to door,</br>Their shining gilt and pictures to display:</br>Cups, saucers, plates, and jugs, in fair array,</br>All which the housewives with much longing saw,</br>When she did hold them to the light of day,</br>First wiping off the dingy dust with straw,</br>Then rang them with her thumb, to show they had no flaw.

And she would sell, for shirt or napkin worn,</br>Or aught of linen rags cast by and old;</br>Such things as would the mantel-piece adorn,</br>Or mote the tea or sugar aptly hold;</br>Or jug for ale, with Wellington so bold,</br>Most cunningly depainted thereupon,</br>Or, present for my nephew mote be sold,</br>Whene'er he did his lesson nimbly con:—</br>Thus did the vagrant change for rags, her ware of stone.

Full well they knew, through all the country round</br>What time were holden races, tryst, and fair,</br>And with much joyance to the merry ground,</br>Would they, with others of their kind, repair,</br>Where busy chapmen vend their little ware,</br>And ballad-minstrel bawls the noisy song,</br>And Maister Punch displays his wonders rare,</br>And gaping Children thread the tawdry throng</br>The penny rich to spend — ykept in purse too long.

There buxom lasses, trigg'd in kirtles gay,</br>Are seen in bevies, smirking, arm in arm,</br>The clean-wash'd face and ribbon to display,</br>Which mote the swain's delighted bosom charm:</br>Some taste the tapster's glass, to keep them warm,</br>Some get ane lapful of confections nice,</br>And others hurry though the pressing swarm,</br>To buy them gowns and combs of quaint device,</br>And much they love the gear, but sorely grudge the price.

There, too, the vagrant at his trade was seen,</br>Amid ane jolly and obstreperous crew,</br>Yplacing wooden pins upon the green</br>(Temptation great to younkling gambler's view)</br>At which the lads ane oaken bludgeon threw,</br>Or else ane ball, with cunning effort, roll'd;</br>And as the pins fell down, the payment due,</br>Of gingerbread in cakes, was fairly told;</br>And thus the game went on, till all the cakes were sold.

Sometimes the Wheel of Fortune he would guard;</br>Ane painted beard with dingy ha'pence crown'd,</br>Most like unto the sailor's compass card,</br>With needle, too, that spun the fateful round:—</br>"Come try your luck!  a penny or a pound,</br>Ne'er did faint heart a lovely lady win"—</br>He cries; and soon the adventurers abound,</br>The cash deposit, and the needle spin,</br>Whose pausing point they mark with many a growl and grin.

His wife meantime, to chear the list'ning crowd,</br>(Whose mass with creeping foot she moves among),</br>With gaping mouth and tongue ybawling loud,</br>Doth tane the measure of ane rustic song;</br>And while she passen through the idlesse throng,</br>Holding her ballads forth for swain to buy,</br>Her little imps she beareth all along,—</br>To help her music one doth, squalling, try—</br>One sleepeth on her back — one at her side doth cry!

At night, when topers rally from the tent,</br>And brawl and bicker in their maudlin fray,</br>The jolly vagrants to their shelter went,</br>And summ'd the gather'd earnings of the day;</br>Right glad and merry o'er their jubbs were they,</br>The which, in dainty mouthfuls, they would quaff,</br>Their brats, meantime, would round about them play,</br>And munch their crust, and, in their fulness, laugh,</br>Then ligge in nook obscure, and sleep among the chaff.

Sad plight, I ween!  but such as they have borne</br>Throughout their lives in this sojourn below,—</br>To squat together 'mong vile straw to morn,</br>And nowthir counterpane nor blanket know;</br>Then all day long to journey to and fro,</br>Until their little feet are gall'd and sore;</br>And then their legs across the ass they throw,</br>One o'er the rump — one o'er the neck before,—</br>And one in pannier stuff'd, among much other store!

In barn, or bothie, or in miller's kiln,</br>Famed as a houff for their poor pedigree,</br>Or farmer's ha' sometimes at night they fill,</br>And pass the time in merriment and glee,</br>With legends old, some marvellous that be,</br>With songs befitting well the pipe and glass,</br>With telling fortunes, which on cards they see,</br>Meantimes most careful what shall come to pass—</br>Ane lover rich and rare to every buxom lass.

Betimes their urchins, as in years they grew,</br>The parent's age from grievous burden freed,</br>Though in the world 'twas little that they knew,</br>Ne having learnt to spell, much less to read;</br>Untutor'd also in the Christian creed,</br>They found them names, though 'twas not at the fount;</br>In moral garden each ane sorry weed.</br>Untaught to turn their lives to wise account,</br>And so it fared with them — dishonour was th' amount.

Their first-born, Walter, (oftener Wattie hight,)</br>Was taught his father's art of grinding knives;</br>Eftsoons he left such mean, but honest plight,</br>And join'd some secret horde of lawless lives;</br>Drones were they all within the public hives,</br>Whose talk and knowledge were base art and slang;</br>Whose heads in pillory, and feet in gyves,</br>And swinging bodie oft in chains did hang,—</br>Ah!  God forfend ilk man from such a worthless gang!

In soldier's coat and cap, their second son</br>Was finely dight, and march'd to regions far,</br>To push the bay'net, and to fire the gun,</br>Or hurl the gaping cannon on its car;</br>But soon he languish'd in the toils of war,</br>Forsook his post, and cowardly ran off;</br>But being known full well by certain scar,</br>He was secur'd, and forced, perdie, to doff</br>His coat to cruel lash, amid his comrades' scoff.

Bes was the third-born of this vagrant fry;</br>Fair, though she frown'd, but lovely when she smil'd;</br>She had a cunning witchcraft in her eye,</br>Which mov'd the heart with glances keen and wild:</br>But, ah!  this lovely lass was soon beguil'd—</br>Herself the mother of ane dainty boy;</br>And she did walk the country with her child,</br>By palmistry portending other's joy,</br>While care, and want, and grief, her comfort did destroy!

Some other imps sprung from the vagrant pair:</br>As Rob, with bludder lip and scarlet nose;</br>And Tam, with head ycrown'd with ruddy hair;</br>And Jock, with eyne and cheeks all blue with blows.</br>These in succession, up to manhood rose,</br>And raked the world in search of daily food;</br>As for their occupation, I suppose</br>'Twas of a kind by secrets understood;</br>But whatsoe'er it was — it savour'd not of good.

To ken their fate the veil we dare not draw,</br>Though well I guess what chances may befal:</br>Some throttled by the villains of the law,</br>And led, in dolorous plight, to justice-hall;</br>Therein arraign'd for noisy midnight brawl,</br>Or pilfering coin from lieges' careless pouch;</br>While they, beholding judges clerks, and all,</br>And sullen watchmen, who the deeds can vouch—</br>They stoopen low their heads into ane humble slouch:

And one is sent to Bridewell's dreary cell</br>To work the mill (the lazy miscreant's dread);</br>He for a certain season there must dwell,</br>On bread and water daily to be fed:</br>And one through pillory shows his grinning head,</br>The while the mob him hail with muddy slime;</br>And, peradventure, one is doom'd to tread</br>The lonely ground beneath a foreign clime,</br>Exil'd from native land, to expiate his crime.

Ah, me!  how luckless is the vagrant's fate,</br>Doom'd to ane life of penury and cold!</br>Ne can they boast of lordly high estate,</br>Albeit their pedigree is staunch and old;</br>Shreds, they are call'd, of true Egyptian mould,</br>Or of the ancient minstrels of our land,</br>Who harp'd the deeds of barons brave and bold,</br>And loves of ladies touch'd by magic wand:—</br>Alak!  those witching scenes are banish'd from our strand!

I might have writ a tale of fancied good</br>With much odd learning setting forth of truth;</br>But I was not in such didactic mood,</br>Nor do I love great tomes of prose — good sooth.</br>Yet, though my verse is rugged and uncouth,</br>And somewhat savours of ane bygone age,</br>Both eyes of spectacles, and eyes of youth,</br>May see some things that shall their hearts engage:</br>So here my rhyme is done:  so also is this page.</br>
